elements.content: Six daughter complexes based on two-dimensional (2-D) luminescent Cu4I4–Cu3Pz3 (Pz = pyrazolate) coordination networks, which exhibit an uncommon Cu4I4L3L′ (L = pyridine; L′ = acetonitrile, pyridine, pyrazine, 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]­octane, triphenylphosphine, none) local configuration, were prepared through a postsynthetic modification method starting from a parent complex (L′ = NH3). This work has successfully implemented the single-site substitution of Cu4I4-based coordination frameworks, which have rarely been reported for isolated Cu4I4-type compounds, by taking advantage of the solvent-assisted ligand substitution strategy recently developed in metal–organic framework (MOF) chemistry. Such a procedure not only resulted in the variation of local geometry in the Cu4I4 units but also led to interlayer network displacement and entanglement. Particularly, an interesting topological transformation (from 2-D to 2-D → 3-D interpenetration) occurred when linear bidentate linkers (e.g., pyrazine and 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]­octane) are inserted between the 2-D layers. Moreover, the variation in the L′ sites can effectively tune the emission colors, ranging from green to orange (λem max 540–605 nm at room temperature). The photoluminescence origins are tentatively assigned to be a mixture of 3MLCT and 3XLCT, different from that of the well-studied isolated Cu4I4-type complexes.

This work has successfully implemented the single-site substitution of Cu4I4-based coordination frameworks, which have rarely been reported for isolated Cu4I4-type compounds, by taking advantage of the solvent-assisted ligand substitution strategy recently developed in metal-organic framework (MOF) chemistry. Such a procedure not only resulted in the variation of local geometry in the Cu4I4 units but also led to interlayer network displacement and entanglement. Moreover, the variation in the L' sites can effectively tune the emission colors, ranging from green to orange (λem max 540-605 nm at room temperature). elements.content: A postsynthetic method has been introduced to prepare a series of Cu4I4−Cu3Pz3 (Pz = pyrazolate) based coordination networks, implementing single-site modification on the Cu4I4Py3L′ (Py = pyridine) sites via the anchoring ligand L′ (L′ = acetonitrile, pyridine, pyrazine, 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]­octane, triphenylphosphine, none) substitution. The postsynthetic ligand substitution not only results in a rare topological transformation but also provides new insight into understanding the photoluminescence behaviors of networked Cu4I4-type complexes.

The postsynthetic ligand substitution not only results in a rare topological transformation but also provides new insight into understanding the photoluminescence behaviors of networked Cu4I4-type complexes.

elements.content: Luminescent copper­(I) coordination complexes and clusters have gained much attention in the fields of molecular/supramolecular photophysics and photochemistry due to their rich excited-state properties and practical applications, especially for the copper­(I) halide family (e.g., Cu4I4-type compounds), owing to the contributions of Hardt, Ford, and many groups later. Recently, these classical CuI-based compounds have been investigated systematically toward achieving high-performance hybrid lighting phosphors with excellent thermal and light stability, many of which exhibit one- to three-dimensional (1-D, 2-D, and 3-D) networked structures.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Luminescent copper(I) coordination complexes and clusters have gained much attention in the fields of molecular/supramolecular photophysics and photochemistry due to their rich excited-state properties and practical applications, especially for the copper(I) halide family (e.g., Cu4I4-type compounds), owing to the contributions of Hardt, Ford, and many groups later. Recently, these classical CuI-based compounds have been investigated systematically toward achieving high-performance hybrid lighting phosphors with excellent thermal and light stability, many of which exhibit one- to three-dimensional (1-D, 2-D, and 3-D) networked structures.

elements.content: Concerning solid-state lighting materials, it should be desirable to manipulate the spatial distribution of the luminophores and to modify the local functional sites while retaining the global network topology. Thanks to the recent development in metal–organic framework (MOF) chemistry, it is now possible to implement building block replacement for targeted applications through postsynthetic solvent-assisted ligand substitution and metal metathesis strategies.
elements.clean_text: Concerning solid-state lighting materials, it should be desirable to manipulate the spatial distribution of the luminophores and to modify the local functional sites while retaining the global network topology. Thanks to the recent development in metal-organic framework (MOF) chemistry, it is now possible to implement building block replacement for targeted applications through postsynthetic solvent-assisted ligand substitution and metal metathesis strategies.

elements.content: Our group has been interested continuously in copper­(I) clusters, such as copper­(I) halides and copper­(I) pyrazolates, in isolated and networked systems, which involve intra- and/or intermolecular Cu–Cu interactions and exhibit tunable solid-state phosphorescence. Recently, we succeeded in incorporating two classical copper­(I) cluster luminophores, i.e. Cu4I4 and [Cu3Pz3]2 (Pz = pyrazolate) (), within a crystalline supramolecular dual-emissive system. Three two-dimensional binary-cluster-based coordination networks, namely, [(Cu4I4)­(NH3)­Cu3(L1)3] n (1·NH3), [(Cu4I4)­(NH2CH3)­Cu3(L1)3] n (1·NH2CH3), and [(Cu4I4)­Cu3(L2)3] n (2) (L1 = 3-(4-pyridyl)-5-(p-tolyl)­pyrazolate; L2 = 3-(4-pyridyl)-5-(2,4-dimethylphenyl)­pyrazolate), were prepared from a symmetry-guided self-assembly approach.
elements.clean_text: Our group has been interested continuously in copper(I) clusters, such as copper(I) halides and copper(I) pyrazolates, in isolated and networked systems, which involve intra- and/or intermolecular Cu-Cu interactions and exhibit tunable solid-state phosphorescence. Recently, we succeeded in incorporating two classical copper(I) cluster luminophores, i.e. Cu4I4 and [Cu3Pz3]2 (Pz = pyrazolate) (), within a crystalline supramolecular dual-emissive system. Three two-dimensional binary-cluster-based coordination networks, namely, [(Cu4I4)(NH3)Cu3(L1)3] n  (1⋅NH3), [(Cu4I4)(NH2CH3)Cu3(L1)3] n  (1⋅NH2CH3), and [(Cu4I4)Cu3(L2)3] n  (2) (L1 = 3-(4-pyridyl)-5-(p-tolyl)pyrazolate; L2 = 3-(4-pyridyl)-5-(2,4-dimethylphenyl)pyrazolate), were prepared from a symmetry-guided self-assembly approach.

elements.content: Two classical copper­(I) clusters serving as building blocks in 1·NH3: (a) Cu4I4 unit with NH3 as an anchoring ligand; (b) dimeric [Cu3Pz3]2 unit with a staggered stacking mode. Color codes: red, Cu; blue, N; black, C; purple, I; gray, H. Cu–Cu interactions are shown in green.

elements.content: Subsequently, we attempted to prepare more compounds in this family of Cu4I4–Cu3Pz3 coordination networks by introducing other anchoring ligands in place of the coordinated NH3 (see a) or NH2CH3. However, direct synthesis did not succeed; therefore, we sought a postsynthetic route by taking advantage of such a method developed in MOF chemistry. Starting from the parent complex 1·NH3, we have selected some monodentate (e.g., CH3CN and pyridine (Py)) and bidentate (e.g., pyrazine (Pyz) and 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]­octane (DABCO)) N-donor ligands, as well as a P-donor ligand (triphenylphosphine (PPh3)), for running the postsynthetic ligand substitution reactions. In the present work, six daughter complexes, namely, [Cu4I4Cu3(L1)3] n (3), {[Cu4I4·(CH3CN)­Cu3(L1)3]·CH3CN} n (3·CH3CN), [Cu4I4·(Py)­Cu3(L1)3] n (3·Py), [Cu4I4·(Pyz)1/2Cu3(L1)3] n (4·Pyz), [Cu4I4·(DABCO)1/2Cu3(L1)3] n (4·DABCO), and [Cu4I4·(PPh3)­Cu3(L1)3] n (5·PPh3), are obtained through solvent-assisted ligand substitution (). They give colorful emissions ranging from green to orange (λem max 540–605 nm at room temperature), dependent on the variation in L′. The photoluminescence origins are tentatively assigned to be a mixture of 3MLCT and 3XLCT.

elements.content: Commercially available chemicals were purchased and used without further purification. Infrared spectra (IR) were obtained in KBr disks on a Nicolet Avatar 360 FTIR spectrometer in the range of 4000–400 cm–1. Elemental analyses (EA) of C, H, and N were determined with an Elementar Vario EL III CHNS analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a TA Instruments Q50 Thermogravimetric Analyzer under a nitrogen flow of 40 mL min–1 at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments were performed on a D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

Commercially available chemicals were purchased and used without further purification. Infrared spectra (IR) were obtained in KBr disks on a Nicolet Avatar 360 FTIR spectrometer in the range of 4000-400 cm-1. Elemental analyses (EA) of C, H, and N were determined with an Elementar Vario EL III CHNS analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a TA Instruments Q50 Thermogravimetric Analyzer under a nitrogen flow of 40 mL min-1 at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments were performed on a D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer.

elements.content: Steady-state photoluminescence spectra and lifetime measurements were measured by an Edinburgh FLS920 single photon counting spectrometer equipped with a continuous Xe900 xenon lamp, a μF900 μs flash lamp, a red-sensitive Peltier-cooled Hamamatsu R928P photomultiplier tube (PMT), and a closed-cycle cryostat using liquid helium as cooling medium (Advanced Research Systems). The corrections of excitation and emission for the detector response were performed ranging from 200 to 900 nm. The data were analyzed by iterative convolution of the luminescence decay profile with the instrument response function using the software package provided by Edinburgh Instruments. Lifetime data were fitted with biexponential decay functions. The goodness of the nonlinear least-squares fit was judged by the reduced χ2 value (<1.5 in most cases), the randomness of the residuals, and the autocorrelation function.

elements.content: The parent complex 1·NH3 was synthesized beforehand according to our previous report. The bulk crystals of 1·NH3 were ground into powder microcrystalline samples for the postsynthetic reactions. The yields of the resultants are low (usually less than 10%); therefore, the crystalline samples of the daughter complexes were picked up manually under a microscope (40× amplification) after being washed with ethanol and acetonitrile and then dried in air. The phase purity of the samples was assured by elemental analysis and PXRD measurement (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
Postsynthetic Solvent-Assisted Reactions

The parent complex 1⋅NH3 was synthesized beforehand according to our previous report. The bulk crystals of 1⋅NH3 were ground into powder microcrystalline samples for the postsynthetic reactions. The yields of the resultants are low (usually less than 10%); therefore, the crystalline samples of the daughter complexes were picked up manually under a microscope (40× amplification) after being washed with ethanol and acetonitrile and then dried in air. The phase purity of the samples was assured by elemental analysis and PXRD measurement (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: Caution! In the solvothermal synthesis, the volume of the solution should not exceed half of the volume of the glass tubes to avoid overloading. Be careful to avoid potential empyrosis and incised wound when flame-sealing and opening the glass tubes.

elements.content: A mixture of the parent complex 1·NH3 (17 mg) and acetonitrile (3 mL) was sealed in a 6 mL Pyrex tube, heated in an oven at 140 °C for 72 h, and then slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of −5 °C h–1. Orange-red tinny block crystals were generated on the gas–liquid contact region above the mother liquid, and they were attached on the inside wall of the Pyrex tube. Anal. Calcd for C45H36N9Cu7I4: C, 32.65; H, 2.19; N, 7.62. Found: C, 32.55; H, 2.43; N, 7.41. IR data (KBr, cm–1): 3057 w, 3012 w, 2915 w, 1616 vs, 1475 vs, 1421 s, 1218 m, 1003 m, 820 m, 795 s, 713 m. Note: if the Pyrex tube was kept still for 1 week at room temperature, the orange-red tinny block crystals turned into orange-yellow crystals (3·CH3CN) while the crystal shape was maintained.

Orange-yellow tinny block crystals were generated on the gas–liquid contact region above the mother liquid, and they were attached on the inside wall of the glass tube. Anal. Calcd for C49H42N11Cu7I4: C, 33.87; H, 2.44; N, 8.87. Found: C, 33.65; H, 2.33; N, 8.72. IR data (KBr, cm–1): 3060 w, 3012 w, 2916 w, 2120 w, 2022 w, 1611 vs, 1483 vs, 1421 s, 1216 m, 1088 vs, 1065 m, 823 m, 800 s, 715 m. Note: complexes 3 and 3·CH3CN can undergo single-crystal to single-crystal transformation to each other. The orange-red crystals of 3 can turn into orange-yellow crystals of 3·CH3CN on immersion in acetonitrile for 3 days, while 3·CH3CN can turn into 3 when it is heated at 180 °C under vacuum for 12 h.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data collection was performed on an Oxford Diffraction Gemini E (Enhance Mo X-ray source, Kα, λ = 0.71073 Å) equipped with a graphite monochromator and ATLAS CCD detector (CrysAlis CCD, Oxford Diffraction Ltd.) under a cold nitrogen stream (100 K). The data were processed using CrysAlis RED, Oxford Diffraction Ltd. (Version 1.171.34.44, release 25-10-2010 CrysAlis171.NET). Structures were solved by direct methods (SHELXTL-97) and refined on F 2 using full-matrix least squares (SHELXTL-97).15 All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters, and all hydrogen atoms were included in calculated positions and refined with isotropic thermal parameters riding on those of the parent atoms. The crystal of complex 3·CH3CN was twinned by pseudomerihedry with two components (in the ratio 0.46:0.54 as determined in data reduction). The crystal of complex 5·PPh3 crystallized as a reverse twin and was refined with the TWIN command. Crystal data and structure refinement parameters are summarized in Table S1 in the Supporting Information. Selected bond lengths and angles are given in Tables S2 and S3 in the Supporting Information. CCDC files 1063440–1063447 contain the crystallographic data for this paper.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data collection was performed on an Oxford Diffraction Gemini E (Enhance Mo X-ray source, Kα, λ = 0.71073 Å) equipped with a graphite monochromator and ATLAS CCD detector (CrysAlis CCD, Oxford Diffraction Ltd.) under a cold nitrogen stream (100 K). The data were processed using CrysAlis RED, Oxford Diffraction Ltd. (Version 1.171.34.44, release 25-10-2010 CrysAlis171.NET). Structures were solved by direct methods (SHELXTL-97) and refined on F 2 using full-matrix least squares (SHELXTL-97).15 All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters, and all hydrogen atoms were included in calculated positions and refined with isotropic thermal parameters riding on those of the parent atoms. The crystal of complex 3⋅CH3CN was twinned by pseudomerihedry with two components (in the ratio 0.46:0.54 as determined in data reduction). The crystal of complex 5⋅PPh3 crystallized as a reverse twin and was refined with the TWIN command. Crystal data and structure refinement parameters are summarized in Table S1 in the Supporting Information. Selected bond lengths and angles are given in Tables S2 and S3 in the Supporting Information. CCDC files 1063440-1063447 contain the crystallographic data for this paper.

elements.content: For all of the postsynthetic reactions in this work, we observed that the postsynthesis experienced a decomposition–regeneration process (i.e., the parent complex was sacrificed while the daughter complexes were rebirthed), which was confirmed by the following characterizations. First, a large amount of residual samples of the parent complex remained in the mother liquids, but they lost the original crystal shape and crystallinity, giving poor PXRD patterns (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information) because of partial decomposition. Second, the crystals of the daughter complexes were gathered around the gas–liquid contact region above the mother liquids and attached on the inner wall of the tubes (; see also Figure S3 in the Supporting Information), which exhibit completely different crystal shapes from the parent crystals. Third, the mother liquids turned from colorless to light yellow after the postsynthetic reactions. Mass spectrum analysis of the residual solution showed a maximum peak at m/z 236.3 (m + 1), attributed to the protonated ligand H2 L1 + (Figure S4 in the Supporting Information), confirming the partial decomposition of the parent complex.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Solvent-Assisted Ligand Substitution

For all of the postsynthetic reactions in this work, we observed that the postsynthesis experienced a decomposition-regeneration process (i.e., the parent complex was sacrificed while the daughter complexes were rebirthed), which was confirmed by the following characterizations. First, a large amount of residual samples of the parent complex remained in the mother liquids, but they lost the original crystal shape and crystallinity, giving poor PXRD patterns (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information) because of partial decomposition. Second, the crystals of the daughter complexes were gathered around the gas-liquid contact region above the mother liquids and attached on the inner wall of the tubes (; see also Figure S3 in the Supporting Information), which exhibit completely different crystal shapes from the parent crystals. Third, the mother liquids turned from colorless to light yellow after the postsynthetic reactions. Mass spectrum analysis of the residual solution showed a maximum peak at m/z 236.3 (m + 1), attributed to the protonated ligand H2 L1 + (Figure S4 in the Supporting Information), confirming the partial decomposition of the parent complex.

elements.content: All six daughter complexes could not be prepared directly from the component reactants (HL1, CuI, and the anchoring ligands, i.e. CH3CN, Py, Pyz, DABCO, or PPh3) in acetonitrile or other common solvents. The postsynthetic ligand substitution in this system was most feasibly assisted by acetonitrile solvent, but it did not happen in other common solvents such as water, methanol, ethanol, N,N′-dimethylformide (DMF), tetrahydrofuran (THF), benzene, and toluene. We also found that a higher reaction temperature would facilitate the postsynthetic reactions. However, the reaction mechanism, especially the role of the acetonitrile solvent, and the crystal regeneration process remain unclear.

elements.content: Here, an exception to the decomposition–regeneration situation is the transformation of the crystals of 3 and 3·CH3CN into each other in a single-crystal to single-crystal fashion (see the ). The EA and TGA results (Figure S5a in the Supporting Information) indicated that there is no coordinated CH3CN molecule or solvent inclusion in the crystals of 3. After the single-crystal to single-crystal transformation, the crystal structures of the regenerated 3·CH3CN and 3 can still be determined (labeled 3′·CH3CN and 3′; see Table S1 in the Supporting Information). The transformation could be repeated for several cycles.

elements.content: In the field of MOFs, Hupp, Farha, and co-workers termed the strategy of postsynthetic ligand substitution as solvent-assisted ligand incorporation (acronym SALI) in the case where the exchanged ligand is a nonbridging (anchoring) one. The SALI processes usually take place in a heterogeneous fashion, with unaltered network topology and without degradation or collapse of the parent frameworks. To distinguish SALI from our situation, which clearly involves a crystal decomposition–regeneration process, we propose the extended term solvent-assisted ligand incorporation via rebirth (acronym SALIR).

To distinguish SALI from our situation, which clearly involves a crystal decomposition-regeneration process, we propose the extended term solvent-assisted ligand incorporation via rebirth (acronym SALIR).

elements.content: After the postsynthetic ligand substitution, the resulting daughter complexes 3·CH3CN, 3·Py, 4·Pyz, 4·DABCO, and 5·PPh3 adopt a Cu4I4Py3L′ local configuration, while in complex 3 the Cu4I4 unit has a vacant site (). The single-site modification also changes the point symmetry of the Cu4I4 clusters and also the space group of the crystals, leading to different crystal shapes of the daughter complexes (b; see also Figure S3 in the Supporting Information). For example, installation of a CH3CN molecule into the vacant site of Cu4I4 in 3 directly reduces the crystal symmetry from trigonal R3̅ to triclinic P1̅ for 3·CH3CN, similar to the situation in 1·NH2CH3. The included additional CH3CN guests in the crystal lattice (Figure S7 in the Supporting Information) may also lead to the reduction of the crystal symmetry of complex 3·CH3CN. These coordinated and included CH3CN molecules were further evidenced by IR, EA, and TGA.

elements.content: Remarkably, such a single-site modification is rarely observed in reported Cu4I4L4 complexes, which offers an opportunity for using the exposed CuI reactive sites for single-site catalysis, especially for the three-coordinated CuI site in the Cu4I4 unit of 3 (see a, which is also observed in 2 ).

elements.content: Although both the ideal Cu4I4 or Cu3Pz3 clusters and the honeycomb net are achiral, the 2-D layer in this family of complexes is chiral. The supramolecular chirality arises from the steric hindrance of the ligand substituents surrounding the periphery of the Cu3Pz3 clusters (). The Cu3(L1)3 units thus exhibit a chiral Λ or Δ configuration with the C3 (or pseudo-C3 for 3·CH3CN) point symmetry. In each single layer the Cu3(L1)3 units have the same chiral conformation, leading to a chiral 2-D sheet. However, 2-D layers with opposite handedness are packed alternately in the crystals, thus giving rise to the centrosymmetric R3̅ space group for 3, 3·Py, 4·Pyz, and 4·DABCO, and P1̅ for 3·CH3CN.
elements.clean_text:
Diastereoisomer-Like Supramolecular Chirality

Although both the ideal Cu4I4 or Cu3Pz3 clusters and the honeycomb net are achiral, the 2-D layer in this family of complexes is chiral. The supramolecular chirality arises from the steric hindrance of the ligand substituents surrounding the periphery of the Cu3Pz3 clusters (). The Cu3(L1)3 units thus exhibit a chiral Λ or Δ configuration with the C3 (or pseudo-C3 for 3⋅CH3CN) point symmetry. In each single layer the Cu3(L1)3 units have the same chiral conformation, leading to a chiral 2-D sheet. However, 2-D layers with opposite handedness are packed alternately in the crystals, thus giving rise to the centrosymmetric R3̅ space group for 3, 3⋅Py, 4⋅Pyz, and 4⋅DABCO, and P1̅ for 3⋅CH3CN.

elements.content: Pair of mirror images of Cu3(L1)3 units showing Λ and Δ conformations.
elements.clean_text: 6  Pair of mirror images of Cu3(L1)3 units showing Λ and Δ conformations.

elements.content: Interestingly, a special situation exists for 5·PPh3, which crystallizes in the chiral P63 space group. There are two crystallographically independent fragments with the same chemical composition, the same coordination geometry, and very slightly different bond lengths and angles in its asymmetric unit (a and Tables S2 and S3 in the Supporting Information). Each can be generated to one independent 2-D chiral sheet. Similar with the case for other complexes of this family, in each sheet all of the Cu3(L1)3 units show the same chiral conformation (Λ/Δ), and all of the PPh3 groups show the same propeller-like chirality (Δ/Λ) (b), leading to chiral 2-D sheets. The two adjacent sheets show opposite handedness; however, they are not a pair of enantiomers because of the different bond lengths and angles between them. Such a situation is similar to a pair of diastereoisomers (instead of enantiomers)a typical example is our left and right hands, which are not the mirror images of each other (inserted picture in b). Such a phenomenon has rarely been reported, and the reasons for this formation are still under investigation. Unfortunately, two enantiopure crystals of 5·PPh3 with opposite handedness grew in twin (see the ), which prevented us from studying the chirality-related properties.

The two adjacent sheets show opposite handedness; however, they are not a pair of enantiomers because of the different bond lengths and angles between them. Such a situation is similar to a pair of diastereoisomers (instead of enantiomers)a typical example is our left and right hands, which are not the mirror images of each other (inserted picture in b). elements.content: Due to the crystal decomposition–regeneration process in the postsynthetic ligand substitution, the daughter complexes exhibit different stacking modes of the 2-D layers (i.e., showing network displacement) in comparison with that of the parent 1·NH3. To compare the diverse interlayer packings in all nine complexes in this family (including 1·NH3, 1·NH2CH3, and 2), we label the Cu3Pz3 and Cu4I4 units and the triangular void region within one single layer as the Cu3, I4, and V sites, respectively (see , in which the face and back sides are also denoted). As shown in (see also ), there is only one face-to-face stacking mode (denoted mode I) in all nine complexes but three different back-to-back stacking modes (denoted modes II–IV) with respect to the relative positions of the Cu3, I4, and V sites. The difference in the stacking modes can be mostly attributed to increased steric hindrance of the substituted sites and decreased stacking density after crystal regeneration.
elements.clean_text:
Network Displacement and Entanglement

Due to the crystal decomposition-regeneration process in the postsynthetic ligand substitution, the daughter complexes exhibit different stacking modes of the 2-D layers (i.e., showing network displacement) in comparison with that of the parent 1⋅NH3. To compare the diverse interlayer packings in all nine complexes in this family (including 1⋅NH3, 1⋅NH2CH3, and 2), we label the Cu3Pz3 and Cu4I4 units and the triangular void region within one single layer as the Cu3, I4, and V sites, respectively (see , in which the face and back sides are also denoted). As shown in  (see also ), there is only one face-to-face stacking mode (denoted mode I) in all nine complexes but three different back-to-back stacking modes (denoted modes II-IV) with respect to the relative positions of the Cu3, I4, and V sites. The difference in the stacking modes can be mostly attributed to increased steric hindrance of the substituted sites and decreased stacking density after crystal regeneration.

In the parent complex 1·NH3 (also 1·NH2CH3 and 2), the face-to-face stacking (a) is supported by intertrimeric Cu–Cu interactions (e.g., Cu–Cu distance of 3.59 Å in 1·NH3 ), forming a dimeric [Cu3Pz3]2 unit with a staggered configuration (see b). The anchoring ligands in the I4 sites penetrate the adjacent layer through the void regions to form embedded-like structures. In comparison, in the daughter complexes, the embedded-like structure remains but all the intertrimeric Cu–Cu distances are larger than 4.00 Å, suggesting the absence of Cu–Cu interaction after crystal regeneration.

The anchoring ligands in the I4 sites penetrate the adjacent layer through the void regions to form embedded-like structures. In comparison, in the daughter complexes, the embedded-like structure remains but all the intertrimeric Cu-Cu distances are larger than 4.00 Å, suggesting the absence of Cu-Cu interaction after crystal regeneration.

elements.content: The daughter complexes show much looser back-to-back stacking in comparison with that of the parent complex (b–d, see also Figures S8–S11 in the Supporting Information). Five of the daughters (see ) exhibit a back-to-back stacking mode similar to that of complex 2, giving a V···V positioning with accessible pores (c). Complex 5·PPh3 shows the loosest back-to-back stacking due to the bulkiness of the PPh3 group (see Figure S11 in the Supporting Information). As a result, the accessible voids in the crystal lattice of 3 and 5·PPh3 are about 300–400 Å3.

Complex 5⋅PPh3 shows the loosest back-to-back stacking due to the bulkiness of the PPh3 group (see Figure S11 in the Supporting Information). As a result, the accessible voids in the crystal lattice of 3 and 5⋅PPh3 are about 300-400 Å3.

elements.content: The most interesting structural feature is the occurrence of a topological transformation (i.e., showing network entanglement) for 4·Pyz and 4·DABCO (). One can see that, in complex 3, two vacant three-coordinated CuI sites face against each other (a). When monodentate anchoring ligands are installed at these vacant sites, as in the cases of 3·CH3CN and 3·Py, the local Cu4I4Py3L′ coordination geometry is distorted due to severe steric hindrance (b,c, e.g. π–π interaction of 3.92 Å between interlayer pyridine contacts for 3·Py). Further, when suitable linear bidentate ligands are introduced, as in the case of 4·Pyz and 4·DABCO, the two three-coordinated CuI sites are connected (d,e), giving rise to an overall network entanglement (c; see also Figure S12 in the Supporting Information). Such an uncommon topological feature is categorized as a 2-D → 3-D polycatenated parallel entanglement (PCAT, 3,4L88, Doc = 2, Is = 1) according to Carlucci et al.
elements.clean_text: The most interesting structural feature is the occurrence of a topological transformation (i.e., showing network entanglement) for 4⋅Pyz and 4⋅DABCO (). One can see that, in complex 3, two vacant three-coordinated CuI sites face against each other (a). When monodentate anchoring ligands are installed at these vacant sites, as in the cases of 3⋅CH3CN and 3⋅Py, the local Cu4I4Py3L' coordination geometry is distorted due to severe steric hindrance (b,c, e.g. π-π interaction of 3.92 Å between interlayer pyridine contacts for 3⋅Py). Further, when suitable linear bidentate ligands are introduced, as in the case of 4⋅Pyz and 4⋅DABCO, the two three-coordinated CuI sites are connected (d,e), giving rise to an overall network entanglement (c; see also Figure S12 in the Supporting Information). Such an uncommon topological feature is categorized as a 2-D → 3-D polycatenated parallel entanglement (PCAT, 3,4L88, Doc = 2, Is = 1) according to Carlucci et al.

elements.content: The phenomenon of network displacement and entanglement is feasible under the condition that the crystals undergo a decomposition–regeneration process in the postsynthetic reactions. This can be considered an advantage of SALIR in comparison with SALI that is subject to unaltered framework topology. There were sporadic reports on crystal transformation involving entangled 2-D coordination networks, but such a topological transformation from an untangled 2-D network to 2-D → 3-D entanglement through postsynthetic ligand substitution is extremely rare. We envisage that such a postsynthetic method for modifying the global connectedness of coordination networks would bring emergent properties.

elements.content: As a preliminary study of their photophysical properties, we have measured the temperature-dependent excitation and emission spectra () of the daughter complexes 3–5 and also their emission decay lifetimes (see Figure S13 in the Supporting Information). The variation in the L′ sites can effectively tune the emission colors ranging from green to orange (λem max 540–605 nm at room temperature). Some photophysical data of complexes 3–5 are summarized in .
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence Properties of Cu4I4-Cu3Pz3 Coordination Networks

As a preliminary study of their photophysical properties, we have measured the temperature-dependent excitation and emission spectra () of the daughter complexes 3-5 and also their emission decay lifetimes (see Figure S13 in the Supporting Information). The variation in the L' sites can effectively tune the emission colors ranging from green to orange (λem max 540-605 nm at room temperature). Some photophysical data of complexes 3-5 are summarized in .

Emission decay lifetimes measured at 298–30 K (see Table S4 in the Supporting Information for details).

In our previously reported 1·NH3 and 1·NH2CH3, supramolecular dual emissions were observed, for which the low-energy emission band (λem max ca. 600–700 nm) is ascribed to the excimeric [Cu3Pz3]2 cluster, while the high-energy emission band (λem max ca. 520–560 nm) corresponds to the Cu4I4 cluster, independently. In the present work, all of the daughter complexes exhibit only one emission band (λem max ca. 540–605 nm at room temperature) attributed to the Cu4I4Py3L′ sites. The absence of the low-energy band is reasonable because the intertrimeric Cu–Cu contacts in the [Cu3Pz3]2 dimer are elongated to such an extent (larger than 4.0 Å) that the photoinduced Cu–Cu bonding can no longer exist in the excited states.

In the present work, all of the daughter complexes exhibit only one emission band (λem max ca. 540-605 nm at room temperature) attributed to the Cu4I4Py3L' sites. The absence of the low-energy band is reasonable because the intertrimeric Cu-Cu contacts in the [Cu3Pz3]2 dimer are elongated to such an extent (larger than 4.0 Å) that the photoinduced Cu-Cu bonding can no longer exist in the excited states.

elements.content: Usually for isolated Cu4I4L4-type complexes the origin of luminescence is attributed to two types of excited states: triplet cluster-centered (3CC) states (λem max ca. 540–620 nm) which are dominant at room temperature (e.g., 298 K) and triplet halide-to-ligand charge transfer (3XLCT) states (λem max ca. 430–500 nm) which become dominant at low temperature (e.g., 195 K). In comparison, there is only one emission band (see for λem max) in the temperature range of 298–30 K for all six complexes in this work ().

In comparison, there is only one emission band (see  for λem max) in the temperature range of 298-30 K for all six complexes in this work ().

elements.content: Recently the Li group has systematically investigated the phosphorescence properties of a large range of isolated and networked (1-D, 2-D, and 3-D) Cu4I4L4-type complexes in the solid state. On the basis of their band structure calculations, they proposed a metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) or XLCT (or a combination of the two) mechanism for the solid-state emission of Cu4I4L4-type complexes containing aromatic ligands, whereas for those with aliphatic ligands the origin is preliminarily CC-based. Accordingly, we tentatively assign the photoluminescence origin in these Cu4I4Py3L′-based coordination networks to be a mixture of 3MLCT and 3XLCT, which is supported by the biexponentially fitted decay lifetimes at the microsecond scale (; see also Figure S13 and Table S4 in the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: Recently the Li group has systematically investigated the phosphorescence properties of a large range of isolated and networked (1-D, 2-D, and 3-D) Cu4I4L4-type complexes in the solid state. On the basis of their band structure calculations, they proposed a metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) or XLCT (or a combination of the two) mechanism for the solid-state emission of Cu4I4L4-type complexes containing aromatic ligands, whereas for those with aliphatic ligands the origin is preliminarily CC-based. Accordingly, we tentatively assign the photoluminescence origin in these Cu4I4Py3L'-based coordination networks to be a mixture of 3MLCT and 3XLCT, which is supported by the biexponentially fitted decay lifetimes at the microsecond scale (; see also Figure S13 and Table S4 in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: Such a MLCT/XLCT assignment is in accordance with the fact that the excitation/emission wavelength is dependent on the variation of the L′ sites in Cu4I4Py3L′. Because there are two types of ligands (Py and L′) attached to the Cu4I4 core, one can then observe two sets of excitation peaks (near 300 and 350 nm, respectively) in the excitation spectra (). A direct comparison can be made between 4·Pyz and 4·DABCO, which exhibit identical network topologies (2-D → 3-D entanglement). The main difference is that Pyz is an aromatic ligand while DABCO is an aliphatic ligand, and therefore the MLCT/XLCT mechanism is inapplicable in the case of L′ = DABCO, resulting in the absence of the ca. 350 nm excitation peak for 4·DABCO (compare parts d and e of ). For 5·PPh3, the PPh3 anchoring ligand may endow a higher-lying MLCT/XLCT excited state, corresponding to the excitation peaks below 300 nm (f). This can also explain the highest-energy emission bands () of 5·PPh3 in this family.

Because there are two types of ligands (Py and L') attached to the Cu4I4 core, one can then observe two sets of excitation peaks (near 300 and 350 nm, respectively) in the excitation spectra (). A direct comparison can be made between 4⋅Pyz and 4⋅DABCO, which exhibit identical network topologies (2-D → 3-D entanglement). The main difference is that Pyz is an aromatic ligand while DABCO is an aliphatic ligand, and therefore the MLCT/XLCT mechanism is inapplicable in the case of L' = DABCO, resulting in the absence of the ca. 350 nm excitation peak for 4⋅DABCO (compare parts d and e of ). For 5⋅PPh3, the PPh3 anchoring ligand may endow a higher-lying MLCT/XLCT excited state, corresponding to the excitation peaks below 300 nm (f). This can also explain the highest-energy emission bands () of 5⋅PPh3 in this family.

elements.content: The above preliminary results indicate that the single-site substitution on the Cu4I4Py3L′ clusters can effectively modulate their luminescence properties, which is a situation rarely considered for traditional Cu4I4L4-type complexes, perhaps due to the difficulty in synthesis. However, the complicated photophysical behaviors in this system remain unclear, which deserve to be studied in depth in the future.
elements.clean_text: The above preliminary results indicate that the single-site substitution on the Cu4I4Py3L' clusters can effectively modulate their luminescence properties, which is a situation rarely considered for traditional Cu4I4L4-type complexes, perhaps due to the difficulty in synthesis. However, the complicated photophysical behaviors in this system remain unclear, which deserve to be studied in depth in the future.

elements.content: In conclusion, we report here a postsynthetic ligand substitution strategy to prepare a series of new complexes in the family of luminescent Cu4I4–Cu3Pz3 coordination networks, which cannot be obtained through direct synthesis. This method, here called solvent-assisted ligand incorporation via rebirth (acronym SALIR), by taking advantage of recent advances in MOF chemistry, has implemented the single-site modification on the Cu4I4Py3L′ cluster unit within the coordination networks, which has rarely been observed for isolated Cu4I4L4-type compounds. The crystal decomposition-regeneration process accompanying the ligand substitution has warranted network displacement and especially a topological transformation from a 2-D untangled network to 2-D → 3-D entanglement, an advantage superior to common postsynthetic strategies in MOF chemistry that is subject to unaltered framework topology. The photoluminescence properties in this system were tentatively assigned to a mixture of 3MLCT and 3XLCT, suggesting a different luminescence origin for the Cu4I4-based networked compounds in the solid state, in contrast to that for the well-studied isolated Cu4I4-type complexes. Overall, the present contribution demonstrates the postsynthetic method in MOF chemistry is a powerful tool for extending the research scope on the structures and luminescence properties of the classical Cu4I4-type compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, we report here a postsynthetic ligand substitution strategy to prepare a series of new complexes in the family of luminescent Cu4I4-Cu3Pz3 coordination networks, which cannot be obtained through direct synthesis. This method, here called solvent-assisted ligand incorporation via rebirth (acronym SALIR), by taking advantage of recent advances in MOF chemistry, has implemented the single-site modification on the Cu4I4Py3L' cluster unit within the coordination networks, which has rarely been observed for isolated Cu4I4L4-type compounds. The crystal decomposition-regeneration process accompanying the ligand substitution has warranted network displacement and especially a topological transformation from a 2-D untangled network to 2-D → 3-D entanglement, an advantage superior to common postsynthetic strategies in MOF chemistry that is subject to unaltered framework topology. The photoluminescence properties in this system were tentatively assigned to a mixture of 3MLCT and 3XLCT, suggesting a different luminescence origin for the Cu4I4-based networked compounds in the solid state, in contrast to that for the well-studied isolated Cu4I4-type complexes. Overall, the present contribution demonstrates the postsynthetic method in MOF chemistry is a powerful tool for extending the research scope on the structures and luminescence properties of the classical Cu4I4-type compounds.

Interestingly, the French word “salir” means “to get dirty, to mess up” (here implying crystal decomposition), while the Spanish word “salir” means “to leave, to go out” (here implying ligand substitution). Moreover, the unusual network topology emerges as a consequence of “rebirth” (i.e., crystal regeneration).

A mixture of the parent complex 1·NH3 (17 mg) and acetonitrile (3 mL) was sealed in a 6 mL Pyrex tube, heated in an oven at 140 °C for 72 h, and then slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of −5 °C h–1. Orange-red tinny block crystals were generated on the gas–liquid contact region above the mother liquid, and they were attached on the inside wall of the Pyrex tube. Anal. Calcd for C45H36N9Cu7I4: C, 32.65; H, 2.19; N, 7.62. Found: C, 32.55; H, 2.43; N, 7.41. IR data (KBr, cm–1): 3057 w, 3012 w, 2915 w, 1616 vs, 1475 vs, 1421 s, 1218 m, 1003 m, 820 m, 795 s, 713 m. Note: if the Pyrex tube was kept still for 1 week at room temperature, the orange-red tinny block crystals turned into orange-yellow crystals (3·CH3CN) while the crystal shape was maintained.

Complex <bold>3</bold>·CH<sub>3</sub>CN

A mixture of the parent complex 1·NH3 (17 mg) and acetonitrile (3 mL) was sealed in a 6 mL Pyrex tube, heated in an oven at 180 °C for 72 h, and then slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of −5 °C h–1. Orange-yellow tinny block crystals were generated on the gas–liquid contact region above the mother liquid, and they were attached on the inside wall of the glass tube. Anal. Calcd for C49H42N11Cu7I4: C, 33.87; H, 2.44; N, 8.87. Found: C, 33.65; H, 2.33; N, 8.72. IR data (KBr, cm–1): 3060 w, 3012 w, 2916 w, 2120 w, 2022 w, 1611 vs, 1483 vs, 1421 s, 1216 m, 1088 vs, 1065 m, 823 m, 800 s, 715 m. Note: complexes 3 and 3·CH3CN can undergo single-crystal to single-crystal transformation to each other. The orange-red crystals of 3 can turn into orange-yellow crystals of 3·CH3CN on immersion in acetonitrile for 3 days, while 3·CH3CN can turn into 3 when it is heated at 180 °C under vacuum for 12 h.

Complex <bold>3</bold>·Py

A mixture of the parent complex 1·NH3 (17 mg), acetonitrile (3 mL), and 0.1 mL of pyridine was sealed in a 6 mL Pyrex tube, heated in an oven at 180 °C for 72 h, and then slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of −5 °C h–1. Yellow block crystals were generated on the gas–liquid contact region above the mother liquid, and they were attached on the inside wall of the Pyrex tube. Anal.
